newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Ukraine says plans to sell all electricity firms.
newsitem.headline: Ukraine says plans to sell all electricity firms.

text.p: Ukraine, which in March announced plans to privatise 18 of its 31 electrical energy companies, now intends to sell off the rest of the sector, Energy Minister Yuri Bochkaryov told a news conference on Thursday.

"Plans to distribute shares in all the remaining companies where privatisation has not begun have been prepared by the energy ministry and given preliminary consideration by the cabinet of ministers," Bochkaryov said.

He gave no further details on the plans, but the government has said the state would keep a 51 percent stake in the 18 companies already set to be sold off, with up to 30 percent going to a strategic investor and workers getting the rest.
Tenders, open to foreigners, are expected to take place on the first 18 companies in the second and third quarters.

The minister said consumers owed the sector 3.4 billion hryvnias ($1.89 billion) at the start of May after 3.3 billion hryvnias in March. He said the cabinet of ministers planned to implement tough steps soon to reduce the debt.
"We are putting our faith in an order being prepared by the cabinet on tougher payments procedures and we are working very hard on this," he said.

Bochkaryov was re-appointed energy minister this week and his portfolio expanded after President Leonid Kuchma folded the state nuclear regulatory agency into the Energy and Electricity ministry as part of a shake-up of government structures aimed at making them more efficient.
